Hello @yejianquan, 

Could you please share where in the code the test_ro_disk.py makes /tmp to be read-only,
I have tried to run the test with some changes from the master, but I don't find the root cause for this failure to be only on 202205.

> Hello @yejianquan,
> 
> Could you please share where in the code the test_ro_disk.py makes /tmp to be read-only, I have tried to run the test with some changes from the master, but I don't find the root cause for this failure to be only on 202205.

Hi @slutati1536 , as I replied in the email thread, To simulate the read-only disk: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/0d04e848db4b3f5158a4d621abd881430e881046/tests/tacacs/test_ro_disk.py#L33C3-L33C3

> Reference



> can we use the following way for configuration recovery after test. The benefit is once in future other configuration changed we don't need to spend effort again for this kind of cleanup job. You can refer to test_bgp_dual_asn from tests.generic_config_updater.gu_utils import ( create_checkpoint, delete_checkpoint, rollback_or_reload, )

Good idea! I will raise another PR to realise it.

I think this should be fixed as part of the service-warm-restart feature (image fix).

Every service should automatically update the flag after finishing warm restart. Just like how system wide warm reboot flag is unset at the end of warm-reboot.

> I think this should be fixed as part of the service-warm-restart feature (image fix).
> 
> Every service should automatically update the flag after finishing warm restart. Just like how system wide warm reboot flag is unset at the end of warm-reboot.

Yes, that's a good call out. The service should clear the flag after the service warm-restart.
But the test case should also do the cleanup, that is reset the flags to false.

> > I think this should be fixed as part of the service-warm-restart feature (image fix).
> > Every service should automatically update the flag after finishing warm restart. Just like how system wide warm reboot flag is unset at the end of warm-reboot.
> 
> Yes, that's a good call out. The service should clear the flag after the service warm-restart. But the test case should also do the cleanup, that is reset the flags to false.

Ack. As discussed: this test should fail when the service restart is left enabled after the restart has been finished. The testcase owner should fix the issue.

I think it's probably caused by `get_multiple_flows`. Before this change, we are calling `construct_ip_pkt`. It should be a generic change for all platform.

@bingwang-ms : I understand the problem. How does get_mulitple_flows() affect the watermark ? This function sends only one packet at a time to see which port receives it. At this point the dst_port is not even disabled. Is that alone enough to raise the watermark so much ?

@rraghav-cisco I checked the code `get_multiple_flows`. I suspect it's caused by below code.
If `get_rx_port_pkt(dp, src_tuple[0], pkt, masked_exp_pkt) != dst_id`, `num_of_pkts` will not increase. Then the while loop may not end.
```
if get_rx_port_pkt(dp, src_tuple[0], pkt, masked_exp_pkt) == dst_id:
 try:
 all_pkts[src_tuple[0]].append((pkt, masked_exp_pkt))
 num_of_pkts+=1
 except KeyError:
 all_pkts[src_tuple[0]] = []
 all_pkts[src_tuple[0]].append((pkt, masked_exp_pkt.exp_pkt))
 num_of_pkts+=1
```
I haven't got a chance to debug the test case. For now, I suggest improv this PR to limit the change only to cisco platform. We can still call `construct_ip_pkt` and `get_rx_port` on other platforms.
Please let me know how do you think. Thanks!
I reverted this change and run it again, then test can pass. That's why I suspect this change caused the regression.

> The import statement import scapy.arch.pcapdnet likely relies on this configuration being set correctly in order to work as intended.

Do we have a concrete proof for this statement, or is this based solely on observation from experiments?

See https://github.com/secdev/scapy/blob/v2.2.0/scapy/arch/pcapdnet.py#L22 for the code. This import changes the value of `conf.L2listen`, `conf.L3socket`, and `conf.L2socket` only if `conf.use_pcap` is set to `True`.

> > The import statement import scapy.arch.pcapdnet likely relies on this configuration being set correctly in order to work as intended.
> 
> Do we have a concrete proof for this statement, or is this based solely on observation from experiments?
Different sockets are used depending on if conf.use_pcap is enabled. Not sure why it is needed in the first place
>>> conf.use_pcap = True
>>> conf.L2listen
<L2ListenSocket: read packets at layer 2 using Linux PF_PACKET sockets>
>>> import scapy.arch.pcapdnet
>>> conf.L2listen
<L2pcapListenSocket: read packets at layer 2 using libpcap>

hi @ansrajpu-git, thanks for your fix.
I have added some additional change:
1. added a flag `plt_reboot_ctrl_overwrite` in `reboot` function to decide whether we want to overwrite `wait` and `timeout`. by default is to overwrite, in this test `test_reload_configuration_checks` we don't want to wait for that long, we want to catch transient error, so the flag is False.
2. changed to run on every sku with `enum_rand_one_per_hwsku_hostname`

I have confirmed this worked on Arista chassis, please also confirm if it works for your case
